name: Kepler-280
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-280 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-280 is a star with 0.785 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.89 times its radius. It is located 2603.41 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-280 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-280 b

Kepler-280 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.14 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-280.

The mass of Kepler-280 b is 2.33 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-280 b is 1.45 that of Earth. At 2.33 Earth masses, Kepler-280 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-280 c

Kepler-280 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.81 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-280.

The mass of Kepler-280 c is 5.12 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-280 c is 2.01 that of Earth. At 5.12 Earth masses, Kepler-280 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-280, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
